one-rep-max-calculator.title: One Rep Max (1RM) Calculator - Free Strength Tool
one-rep-max-calculator.description: Calculate your estimated one-rep max for any lift. Free online strength and powerlifting performance calculator.

howItWorks.title: How the 1RM Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates the maximum weight you can lift for one repetition based on a weight you lifted for multiple reps. This helps you know your max strength without risking injury from an actual 1RM test.

steps.name: Enter Weight
steps.text: Input the weight you lifted in your last set

steps.name: Enter Reps
steps.text: Input the number of reps you completed with proper form

steps.name: Calculate 1RM
steps.text: The tool applies multiple formulas and gives you the estimate

useCases.title: Programming Workouts
useCases.description: Determine training weights as percentages of 1RM

useCases.title: Measuring Progress
useCases.description: Track strength increases over time

useCases.title: Competition Prep
useCases.description: Estimate attempt weights for powerlifting competitions

seoTips: Use 3-6 reps for more accurate estimates
Ensure reps are performed with proper technique
Recalculate every 4-6 weeks to update your program
Don't attempt actual 1RM tests without a spotter
commonMistakes: Using more than 10 reps which reduces accuracy
Counting reps with poor technique or assistance
Not warming up properly before the test set
Relying on estimates without actually testing weights

faqs.question: How accurate are 1RM estimates?
faqs.answer: Very accurate with 3-6 reps (±5%), accuracy decreases with more reps.

faqs.question: Should I test my actual 1RM?
faqs.answer: Not necessary for beginners - estimates are sufficient. Advanced lifters may need it for competitions.

faqs.question: How do I use 1RM in training?
faqs.answer: Use percentages: 70-80% for hypertrophy, 80-90% for strength, 90%+ for max strength.

workout-volume-calculator.title: Workout Volume Calculator - Daily Training Volume Tool
workout-volume-calculator.description: Calculate your total training volume for strength and hypertrophy. Free online weekly volume tracker for better progress.

howItWorks.title: How the Workout Volume Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates the total training volume you perform weekly. Training volume is the primary driver of muscle growth, and monitoring it helps you progress and avoid overtraining.

steps.name: Enter Sets
steps.text: Input the number of sets for each exercise

steps.name: Enter Reps and Weight
steps.text: Input the reps and weight used

steps.name: Calculate Volume
steps.text: The tool calculates total weekly volume

useCases.title: Progressive Overload
useCases.description: Systematically increase volume to stimulate growth

useCases.title: Avoiding Overtraining
useCases.description: Monitor volume to prevent fatigue and injuries

useCases.title: Comparing Programs
useCases.description: Evaluate effectiveness of different training programs

seoTips: Increase volume by 5-10% weekly for continuous progress
Monitor volume for each muscle group separately
10-20 sets per muscle group weekly is optimal
Reduce volume during deload weeks
commonMistakes: Increasing volume too quickly causing fatigue
Focusing on volume only and neglecting intensity
Not tracking volume for each muscle group
Comparing your volume to others at different levels

faqs.question: What's optimal volume for hypertrophy?
faqs.answer: 10-20 sets per muscle group weekly for intermediate trainees.

faqs.question: Is volume more important than intensity?
faqs.answer: Both matter - volume drives hypertrophy, intensity drives strength.

faqs.question: When should I reduce volume?
faqs.answer: When feeling persistent fatigue, decreased performance, or every 4-6 weeks.

wilks-coefficient-calculator.title: Wilks Coefficient Calculator - Relative Strength Score
wilks-coefficient-calculator.description: Calculate your Wilks score to compare your powerlifting strength across different body weights. Free powerlifting tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Wilks Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Wilks = Total Lifted × Coefficient (based on body weight and gender)
howItWorks.explanation: The Wilks coefficient is a mathematical formula that allows comparing strength between lifters of different weights and genders. It's used in powerlifting competitions to determine the relatively strongest lifter.

steps.name: Enter Data
steps.text: Input your body weight and gender

steps.name: Enter Total
steps.text: Input the sum of your best attempts in all three lifts

steps.name: Calculate Score
steps.text: The tool calculates your Wilks score and performance level

useCases.title: Powerlifting Competitions
useCases.description: Determine the winner between lifters from different weight classes

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Know if your strength is improving relative to your weight

useCases.title: Performance Comparison
useCases.description: Compare yourself against global standards

seoTips: 300+ is considered average, 400+ advanced, 500+ elite
Focus on improving your score rather than comparing to others
Score may decrease if weight increases without strength gains
Use the score to evaluate your program's effectiveness
commonMistakes: Comparing male and female scores (standards are different)
Not using actual best attempts
Entering body weight after eating instead of competition weight
Expecting large score improvements quickly

faqs.question: What's a good Wilks score?
faqs.answer: 300+ average, 400+ advanced, 450+ elite, 500+ world-class for men.

faqs.question: Is Wilks perfect for comparison?
faqs.answer: It's most widely used, but alternatives like DOTS and IPF Points exist.

faqs.question: How do I improve my Wilks score?
faqs.answer: By increasing strength faster than weight, or reducing weight while maintaining strength.

rep-range-calculator.title: Rep Range Calculator - Choose the Right Reps for Your Goal
rep-range-calculator.description: Calculate the best rep ranges for strength, hypertrophy, or endurance. Free online workout planning tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Rep Range Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: Different rep ranges target different muscle adaptations. This calculator helps you choose the right range for your goal and calculates suggested weight based on your 1RM.

steps.name: Set Goal
steps.text: Choose your goal (strength, hypertrophy, endurance)

steps.name: Enter 1RM
steps.text: Input the maximum weight you can lift for one rep

steps.name: View Recommendations
steps.text: The tool shows rep ranges and suggested weights

useCases.title: Workout Programming
useCases.description: Determine reps and weights for each exercise

useCases.title: Changing Goals
useCases.description: Transition from a strength program to hypertrophy or vice versa

useCases.title: Variety
useCases.description: Change rep ranges periodically to avoid plateaus

seoTips: For max strength: 1-5 reps with heavy weights
For hypertrophy: 6-12 reps with moderate-heavy weights
For endurance: 12-20 reps with light-moderate weights
Vary ranges every 4-6 weeks for continuous progress
commonMistakes: Always using the same rep range
Choosing a range that doesn't match your goal
Ignoring the importance of appropriate weight for each range
Not reaching muscle failure on the last set

faqs.question: Which range is best for building muscle?
faqs.answer: 6-12 reps is best for hypertrophy, but variety is beneficial.

faqs.question: Can I build muscle with high reps?
faqs.answer: Yes, if you reach muscle failure, but it's less efficient.

faqs.question: How much rest between sets?
faqs.answer: For strength: 3-5 minutes, for hypertrophy: 1-2 minutes, for endurance: 30-60 seconds.

deload-week-calculator.title: Deload Week Calculator - Active Recovery Planning
deload-week-calculator.description: Determine the right time for a deload week to avoid overtraining and optimize long-term progress. Free fitness tool.

howItWorks.title: How the Deload Week Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Deload Need = Training Weeks × Training Intensity ÷ Experience Level
howItWorks.explanation: A deload week is when you reduce training volume and intensity to allow the nervous system and joints to recover. This tool helps you determine when you need a deload week.

steps.name: Enter Training Weeks
steps.text: Input the number of consecutive intense training weeks

steps.name: Set Intensity
steps.text: Select your current training intensity

steps.name: Set Experience
steps.text: Select your training experience level

useCases.title: Preventing Overtraining
useCases.description: Avoid nervous system and physical fatigue

useCases.title: Periodization Planning
useCases.description: Schedule deload periods in your program

useCases.title: Performance Improvement
useCases.description: Regular deloading improves long-term performance

seoTips: Plan a deload week every 4-6 weeks of intense training
Reduce volume by 40-60% while maintaining intensity
Continue going to the gym but with lighter loads
Use this week to focus on technique
commonMistakes: Ignoring the need for deload and training until injury
Complete rest instead of active deload
Training at the same intensity during deload week
Not regularly scheduling deload weeks

faqs.question: When do I need a deload week?
faqs.answer: Every 4-6 weeks for advanced, every 6-8 weeks for beginners.

faqs.question: How do I deload?
faqs.answer: Reduce volume by 40-60% while maintaining or slightly reducing weights.

faqs.question: Does deloading weaken muscles?
faqs.answer: No, one week doesn't cause muscle loss - it allows for growth.

athletic-performance-calculator.title: Athletic Performance Calculator - Assess Fitness Level
athletic-performance-calculator.description: Evaluate your overall athletic performance level and compare against standards for various sports and disciplines.

howItWorks.title: How the Athletic Performance Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Total Score = Average of (Speed + Explosive Power + Upper Body Strength + Lower Body Strength)
howItWorks.explanation: This tool evaluates your overall athletic performance based on multiple physical tests. It compares your results to recognized athletic standards to determine your level and strengths and weaknesses.

steps.name: Enter Test Results
steps.text: Input results from speed, jumping, and strength tests

steps.name: Compare to Standards
steps.text: The tool compares your results to athletic standards

steps.name: View Assessment
steps.text: Get overall and detailed scores for each area

useCases.title: Overall Fitness Assessment
useCases.description: Know your general athletic level

useCases.title: Identifying Weaknesses
useCases.description: Find areas that need development

useCases.title: Sport Selection
useCases.description: Find sports that match your abilities

seoTips: Perform tests after a good warm-up
Repeat tests every 2-3 months to track progress
Focus training on your weaknesses
Don't compare yourself to professional athletes
commonMistakes: Testing without adequate warm-up
Testing everything in one day
Focusing only on strengths
Ignoring the importance of endurance and flexibility

faqs.question: What's a good score?
faqs.answer: 60-70% average, 70-80% good, 80%+ excellent for amateurs.

faqs.question: How do I improve my score?
faqs.answer: Through balanced training including strength, speed, and explosive power.

faqs.question: Are the tests accurate?
faqs.answer: Estimated, but they give a good picture of your general level.

training-age-calculator.title: Training Age Calculator - Experience Level Tool
training-age-calculator.description: Assess your training experience level based on gym years and consistency. Free tool for realistic progress expectations.

howItWorks.title: How the Training Age Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Training Age = Years of consistent training accounting for breaks
howItWorks.explanation: Training age differs from actual years of training. It considers training quality and consistency. This helps determine your true experience level and appropriate programming.

steps.name: Enter Start Date
steps.text: Input when you started regular training

steps.name: Account for Breaks
steps.text: The tool calculates break periods if any

steps.name: Determine Level
steps.text: The tool determines your experience level (beginner, intermediate, advanced)

useCases.title: Training Programming
useCases.description: Choose a program that fits your experience level

useCases.title: Realistic Expectations
useCases.description: Understand what can be achieved at your level

useCases.title: Progress Planning
useCases.description: Determine the next phase in your training journey

seoTips: Beginners (0-1 year) progress quickly with any reasonable program
Intermediates (1-3 years) need better programming
Advanced (3+ years) need specialized programs
Long breaks reduce effective training age
commonMistakes: Considering gym membership years as training age
Ignoring breaks and inconsistent training periods
Choosing advanced programs for beginners
Undervaluing actual experience

faqs.question: What's the difference between training age and actual years?
faqs.answer: Training age only counts effective and consistent training.

faqs.question: Do I become a beginner again after a long break?
faqs.answer: Partially, but muscle memory helps you recover faster.

faqs.question: How does training age affect progress?
faqs.answer: As training age increases, progress slows and you need better programming.

vertical-jump-calculator.title: Vertical Jump Calculator - Jump Height and Power
vertical-jump-calculator.description: Calculate your vertical jump height and explosive lower-body power. Free online tool for athletes and dunkers.

howItWorks.title: How the Vertical Jump Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Jump Height = Reach at Jump - Standing Reach, Power (W) = √(4.9 × body weight × jump height) × 9.81
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your vertical jump height and explosive power for lower body muscles. Vertical jump is an important indicator of explosive power needed in most sports.

steps.name: Measure Standing Reach
steps.text: Measure the highest point you can reach while standing flat-footed

steps.name: Measure Jump Reach
steps.text: Measure the highest point you reach at the top of your jump

steps.name: Calculate Height and Power
steps.text: The tool calculates jump height and explosive power

useCases.title: Athlete Assessment
useCases.description: Important in basketball, volleyball, and track and field

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Track explosive power improvements with training

useCases.title: Fitness Testing
useCases.description: Part of fitness tests in most sports

seoTips: Warm up well before testing
Jump multiple times and take the best attempt
Use arm swing to improve jump
40-50 cm is good for amateurs, 60+ cm for athletes
commonMistakes: Not warming up adequately before testing
Testing after an exhausting workout
Not using proper jumping technique
Jumping from movement instead of standing

faqs.question: What's a good vertical jump?
faqs.answer: 40-50 cm average, 50-60 cm good, 60+ cm excellent for adult males.

faqs.question: How do I improve my jump?
faqs.answer: Through plyometrics, squats, deadlifts, and improving technique.

faqs.question: Does weight affect jumping?
faqs.answer: Yes, reducing body fat and increasing strength improves jumping.

one_rep_max.title: One Rep Max (1RM) Calculator
one_rep_max.description: Calculate the maximum weight you can lift for a single repetition based on your lifts.

tooltips.reps: The number of times you lifted the weight correctly (1-12)

results.title: Estimated Strength Levels
results.note_content: These results are estimates. Actual strength varies based on many factors. Use these numbers as a starting point for your training program.

errors.all_fields: Please enter weight and number of repetitions
errors.invalid_reps: Number of repetitions must be between 1 and 12 for formula accuracy

empty_state.text: Enter weight and reps to calculate your max strength
Enter weight and reps to calculate your max strength

howItWorks.title: How the One Rep Max Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator estimates the maximum weight you can lift for one repetition based on the weight and reps you performed. Multiple scientifically-validated formulas (Epley, Brzycki, Lander) are used to provide an accurate average estimate without risking injury from an actual max attempt.

steps.name: Enter Weight
steps.text: Input the weight you lifted in your working set

steps.name: Enter Reps
steps.text: Input the number of repetitions completed with proper form

steps.name: Calculate 1RM
steps.text: The calculator applies multiple formulas and provides your estimated max

useCases.title: Training Programming
useCases.description: Determine training weights as percentages of your 1RM for different goals

useCases.title: Strength Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor strength gains over time without maxing out

useCases.title: Competition Preparation
useCases.description: Estimate attempt weights for powerlifting meets

seoTips: Use 3-6 reps for the most accurate estimates
Ensure all reps are performed with proper technique
Recalculate every 4-6 weeks to update your training program
Never attempt actual 1RM lifts without proper warm-up and spotters
commonMistakes: Using more than 10 reps which significantly reduces accuracy
Counting reps with poor form or excessive assistance
Not warming up properly before the test set
Attempting actual 1RM tests too frequently

faqs.question: How accurate are 1RM estimates?
faqs.answer: Estimates are most accurate (within 5%) when using 3-6 reps. Accuracy decreases with higher rep counts.

faqs.question: Should I test my actual 1RM?
faqs.answer: Not necessary for most trainees. Estimates work well for programming. Only competitive powerlifters need to test actual maxes.

faqs.question: How do I use 1RM in my training?
faqs.answer: Use percentages: 70-80% for hypertrophy (8-12 reps), 80-90% for strength (3-6 reps), 90%+ for peaking.

athletic_performance.title: Athletic Performance Calculator
athletic_performance.description: Evaluate your overall athletic performance level and compare against standards.
athletic_performance.empty_state: Enter your performance metrics to calculate your score
athletic_performance.footer_note: Scores are approximate and based on general athletic standards.

howItWorks.title: How the Athletic Performance Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Overall Score = Weighted Average of (Speed Score + Power Score + Upper Strength Score + Lower Strength Score)
howItWorks.explanation: This comprehensive tool evaluates your overall athletic performance by testing multiple physical attributes. Each test result is compared against established athletic standards to provide scores in speed, explosive power, and upper and lower body strength.

steps.name: Complete Tests
steps.text: Perform the 40m sprint, vertical jump, bench press, and squat tests

steps.name: Enter Results
steps.text: Input your test results along with your body weight

steps.name: View Assessment
steps.text: Get your overall score and breakdown by athletic attribute

useCases.title: Overall Fitness Assessment
useCases.description: Get an objective measure of your general athletic ability

useCases.title: Weakness Identification
useCases.description: Discover which physical attributes need the most improvement

useCases.title: Sport Selection
useCases.description: Identify sports that align with your natural athletic strengths

seoTips: Perform all tests after a thorough warm-up for accurate and safe results
Retest every 2-3 months to track progress objectively
Focus training on your weakest areas for balanced athletic development
Compare your scores to your own previous results rather than elite athletes
commonMistakes: Testing without adequate warm-up leading to poor performance or injury
Attempting all tests in one day when fatigued
Focusing only on strengths while ignoring weaknesses
Neglecting endurance and flexibility in overall athletic development

faqs.question: What is considered a good overall score?
faqs.answer: 60-70% is average, 70-80% is good, 80%+ is excellent for recreational athletes.

faqs.question: How can I improve my athletic performance score?
faqs.answer: Through balanced training that includes strength, speed, power, and endurance work.

faqs.question: Are these tests accurate measures of athleticism?
faqs.answer: They provide a good general assessment, but sport-specific testing may be more relevant for athletes in particular sports.

deload_week.title: Deload Week Calculator
deload_week.description: Determine the right time for a deload week to avoid overtraining and optimize long-term progress.
deload_week.benefits_desc: Deload weeks allow your central nervous system and joints to recover, preventing injury and promoting long-term strength gains.
deload_week.rec_needed: Your body likely needs recovery. Reduce volume and intensity for one week.
deload_week.rec_ok: You can likely continue training hard for now.
deload_week.empty_state: Enter training details to check deload status
deload_week.footer_note: Listen to your body. If you feel exhausted or performance drops, take a deload.

howItWorks.title: How the Deload Week Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Deload Timing = Training Weeks × Intensity Factor / Experience Level
howItWorks.explanation: A deload week is a planned period of reduced training volume and intensity to allow the nervous system, muscles, and joints to recover fully. This tool analyzes your training history to determine when you need a deload based on accumulated fatigue.

steps.name: Enter Training Weeks
steps.text: Input the number of consecutive weeks of intense training

steps.name: Set Intensity Level
steps.text: Select your current training intensity level

steps.name: Set Experience
steps.text: Select your training experience to factor recovery capacity

useCases.title: Overtraining Prevention
useCases.description: Avoid nervous system fatigue and physical breakdown from excessive training

useCases.title: Training Periodization
useCases.description: Schedule strategic deload periods within your training program

useCases.title: Long-term Progress
useCases.description: Optimize strength and muscle gains by allowing full recovery between training blocks

seoTips: Schedule a deload week every 4-6 weeks of intense training for advanced lifters
Reduce training volume by 40-60% while maintaining weight or slightly reducing it
Continue going to the gym during deload - active recovery is better than complete rest
Use deload weeks to focus on technique and mobility work
commonMistakes: Ignoring fatigue signals and training until injury or burnout
Taking complete rest instead of active deload with reduced volume
Training at the same intensity during deload week, negating recovery benefits
Not scheduling regular deloads and only taking them when forced by injury

faqs.question: When do I need a deload week?
faqs.answer: Every 4-6 weeks for advanced lifters, every 6-8 weeks for intermediates, and when you notice persistent fatigue or declining performance.

faqs.question: How should I structure a deload?
faqs.answer: Reduce volume by 40-60% while maintaining weight or reducing by 10-20%. Keep the same exercises and frequency.

faqs.question: Will I lose strength during a deload?
faqs.answer: No, one week of reduced training does not cause strength loss. You often come back stronger after full recovery.

vertical_jump.title: Vertical Jump Calculator
vertical_jump.description: Calculate your vertical jump height and explosive lower-body power.
vertical_jump.standing_reach_tooltip: Highest point you can touch standing flat
vertical_jump.jump_reach_tooltip: Highest point you can touch at peak of jump
vertical_jump.power_factors_desc: Muscle strength, speed of contraction, and coordination determine your vertical jump power.
vertical_jump.tip_strength: Build leg strength with squats and deadlifts
vertical_jump.tip_technique: Practice proper jumping form and arm swing
vertical_jump.empty_state: Enter reach and weight measurements to calculate jump power
vertical_jump.footer_note: Power calculation uses the Lewis Formula.

howItWorks.title: How the Vertical Jump Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Jump Height = Jump Reach - Standing Reach, Power (W) = sqrt(4.9 × body weight × jump height) × 9.81
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your vertical jump height and explosive power output using the Lewis Formula. Vertical jump is a key indicator of lower-body explosive power, which is critical in many sports including basketball, volleyball, and track and field.

steps.name: Measure Standing Reach
steps.text: Stand flat-footed and reach as high as possible, marking the highest point

steps.name: Measure Jump Reach
steps.text: Jump and touch the highest point possible, recording that height

steps.name: Calculate Power
steps.text: The calculator determines jump height and explosive power output

useCases.title: Athletic Assessment
useCases.description: Evaluate explosive power for sports like basketball, volleyball, and football

useCases.title: Training Progress
useCases.description: Track improvements in explosive power with plyometric and strength training

useCases.title: Fitness Testing
useCases.description: Standard component of athletic fitness testing batteries

seoTips: Warm up thoroughly before testing to prevent injury and maximize results
Take multiple jumps and record the best attempt for accurate measurement
Use proper arm swing technique to maximize jump height
40-50 cm is good for recreational athletes, 60+ cm for competitive athletes
commonMistakes: Not warming up adequately before testing
Testing after an exhausting workout when muscles are fatigued
Using improper jumping technique (no arm swing, bent landing)
Testing from a moving approach instead of a stationary standing position

faqs.question: What is a good vertical jump height?
faqs.answer: 40-50 cm is average for adult males, 50-60 cm is good, 60+ cm is excellent. Female averages are typically 5-10 cm lower.

faqs.question: How can I improve my vertical jump?
faqs.answer: Through plyometric training (box jumps, depth jumps), strength training (squats, deadlifts), and improving jump technique.

faqs.question: Does body weight affect jumping?
faqs.answer: Yes. Reducing excess body fat while maintaining or increasing strength improves power-to-weight ratio and jump height.

workout_volume.title: Workout Volume Calculator
workout_volume.description: Calculate your total training volume for strength and hypertrophy.
workout_volume.tip_progressive: Increase volume gradually over time for progressive overload

howItWorks.title: How the Workout Volume Calculator Works
howItWorks.explanation: This tool calculates your total training volume, which is the primary driver of muscle hypertrophy. Monitoring training volume helps ensure progressive overload while avoiding overtraining and allows comparison between different training programs.

steps.name: Enter Sets
steps.text: Input the number of sets performed for the exercise

steps.name: Enter Reps and Weight
steps.text: Input the repetitions per set and weight used

steps.name: Calculate Volume
steps.text: Get your total weekly volume and per-session breakdown

useCases.title: Progressive Overload
useCases.description: Systematically increase volume over time to stimulate continued muscle growth

useCases.title: Overtraining Prevention
useCases.description: Monitor total volume to prevent excessive fatigue and injuries

useCases.title: Program Comparison
useCases.description: Compare the effectiveness and workload of different training programs

seoTips: Aim to increase weekly volume by 5-10% for continued progress
Track volume per muscle group separately for balanced development
10-20 sets per muscle group weekly is optimal for most intermediate trainees
Reduce volume by 40-50% during deload weeks for recovery
commonMistakes: Increasing volume too quickly, leading to fatigue and potential injury
Focusing only on volume while neglecting training intensity
Not tracking volume for each muscle group individually
Comparing your volume to advanced lifters with different training ages

faqs.question: What is optimal volume for hypertrophy?
faqs.answer: Research suggests 10-20 sets per muscle group per week for intermediate trainees, with beginners needing less and advanced lifters potentially handling more.

faqs.question: Is volume more important than intensity?
faqs.answer: Both matter. Volume primarily drives hypertrophy, while intensity (weight) drives strength. A balance is needed for overall development.

faqs.question: When should I reduce volume?
faqs.answer: When experiencing persistent fatigue, declining performance, or every 4-6 weeks as a planned deload.

wilks_calculator.title: Wilks Coefficient Calculator
wilks_calculator.description: Calculate your Wilks score to compare your powerlifting strength across different body weights.
wilks_calculator.total_lifted_tooltip: Sum of Bench, Squat, and Deadlift
wilks_calculator.empty_state: Enter your stats to calculate Wilks score
wilks_calculator.footer_note: Wilks formula allows comparison between lifters of different weights and genders.
wilks_calculator.info_description: The Wilks Coefficient is used to compare the strength of athletes of different body weights and genders in powerlifting.
wilks_calculator.formula_note: The coefficient uses a formula approved by the International Powerlifting Federation.

howItWorks.title: How the Wilks Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Wilks Score = Total Lifted × Coefficient (based on body weight and gender)
howItWorks.explanation: The Wilks Coefficient is a mathematical formula used in powerlifting to compare relative strength between lifters of different body weights and genders. It normalizes your powerlifting total to allow fair comparison across weight classes.

steps.name: Enter Body Weight
steps.text: Input your current body weight in kilograms

steps.name: Enter Powerlifting Total
steps.text: Input your combined best attempts in squat, bench, and deadlift

steps.name: Calculate Score
steps.text: Get your Wilks score and performance classification

useCases.title: Competition Ranking
useCases.description: Determine the overall winner among powerlifters in different weight classes

useCases.title: Progress Tracking
useCases.description: Monitor if your relative strength improves independent of weight changes

useCases.title: Performance Benchmarking
useCases.description: Compare your strength against national and international standards

seoTips: A Wilks score of 300+ is considered average, 400+ advanced, 500+ elite for men
Focus on improving your Wilks score over time rather than comparing to others
Score may decrease if body weight increases without corresponding strength gains
Use the score to objectively evaluate your training program effectiveness
commonMistakes: Comparing male and female Wilks scores directly (different coefficient curves)
Not using your actual best competition attempts for the total
Entering body weight after eating instead of official weigh-in weight
Expecting large score improvements over short periods

faqs.question: What is a good Wilks score?
faqs.answer: For men: 300+ average, 400+ advanced, 450+ elite, 500+ world class. Women have slightly lower thresholds.

faqs.question: Is Wilks the best comparison formula?
faqs.answer: It is the most widely used, but alternatives like DOTS and IPF Points exist and may be more accurate at extreme body weights.

faqs.question: How can I improve my Wilks score?
faqs.answer: By increasing strength faster than body weight, or by reducing weight while maintaining or increasing strength.

rep_range_calculator.title: Rep Range Calculator
rep_range_calculator.description: Calculate optimal rep ranges based on your training goal.
rep_range_calculator.one_rm_tooltip: Your maximum weight for one repetition
rep_range_calculator.info_description: Different rep ranges target different adaptations.

howItWorks.title: How the Rep Range Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Working Weight = 1RM × Percentage (based on rep range: 85-95% for strength, 65-80% for hypertrophy)
howItWorks.explanation: This tool determines the optimal rep range, working weight, sets, and rest periods based on your training goal. Different rep ranges stimulate different physiological adaptations: lower reps for strength, moderate reps for muscle size, and higher reps for endurance.

steps.name: Select Goal
steps.text: Choose your primary training objective (strength, hypertrophy, endurance)

steps.name: Enter 1RM
steps.text: Input your one-rep max for the exercise

steps.name: Get Recommendations
steps.text: Receive specific rep range, weight, sets, and rest time recommendations

useCases.title: Goal-Specific Training
useCases.description: Train with the optimal parameters for your specific fitness goal

useCases.title: Program Design
useCases.description: Structure your workout program with appropriate rep ranges for each phase

useCases.title: Periodization
useCases.description: Vary rep ranges across training cycles for comprehensive development

seoTips: 1-5 reps at 85-95% 1RM builds maximal strength and neuromuscular efficiency
6-12 reps at 65-80% 1RM maximizes muscle hypertrophy (size)
12-20+ reps at 50-65% 1RM builds muscular endurance
Include multiple rep ranges in your program for balanced development
commonMistakes: Training exclusively in one rep range and missing other adaptations
Using strength rep ranges when hypertrophy is the goal
Not resting long enough for strength work (need 3-5 minutes)
Resting too long for hypertrophy work (reduces metabolic stress)

faqs.question: Which rep range is best for muscle growth?
faqs.answer: 6-12 reps is optimal for hypertrophy, though muscle can be built across all rep ranges with sufficient effort.

faqs.question: How much should rest periods differ?
faqs.answer: Strength: 3-5 minutes, Hypertrophy: 60-90 seconds, Endurance: 30-60 seconds.

faqs.question: Can I mix rep ranges in one workout?
faqs.answer: Yes, starting with heavy compounds (low reps) and finishing with isolation exercises (higher reps) is an effective strategy.

training_age.title: Training Age Calculator
training_age.description: Calculate your training age and experience level.
training_age.start_date_tooltip: When did you start consistent training?
training_age.info_description: Training age affects your recovery ability and programming needs.

howItWorks.title: How the Training Age Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Training Age = Current Date - Training Start Date (in years and months)
howItWorks.explanation: Training age refers to how long you have been consistently training, not your chronological age. It is a critical factor in determining appropriate training volume, intensity, and progression rates. More experienced lifters require different programming than beginners.

steps.name: Enter Start Date
steps.text: Input when you started consistent, structured training

steps.name: Calculate Age
steps.text: The tool calculates your total training time

steps.name: View Classification
steps.text: Get your experience level classification for program design

useCases.title: Program Selection
useCases.description: Choose training programs appropriate for your experience level

useCases.title: Progression Expectations
useCases.description: Set realistic strength and muscle gain expectations based on training experience

useCases.title: Recovery Planning
useCases.description: Understand how your training age affects recovery capacity and volume tolerance

seoTips: Beginners (under 1 year) can make rapid progress with simple programs and linear progression
Intermediate trainees (2-5 years) need periodization and planned progression
Advanced trainees (5+ years) require sophisticated programming with varied stimuli
Training age matters more than chronological age for program design
commonMistakes: Counting years of inconsistent or sporadic training as training age
Using advanced programs when you are still a beginner
Expecting beginner-level gains with years of training experience
Ignoring training age when selecting programs from social media

faqs.question: Why does training age matter?
faqs.answer: It determines your adaptation potential, recovery capacity, and the complexity of programming you need.

faqs.question: Does a training break reset my training age?
faqs.answer: Partially. Muscle memory helps, but extended breaks (1+ years) may reduce effective training age.

faqs.question: Can a beginner use advanced programs?
faqs.answer: Not recommended. Beginners progress faster with simpler programs and would not benefit from the complexity.
